description:
Wow the food is great here. All the staffs are very accommodating and I felt so welcome. their cuisines are the best in town, will recommend them to my friends! I've been craving for this place since the last time we came here so I promised myself that I'm going back here. 

I do blog of great restaurants in places,of course I'll include this place! you can view great restaurants here! - https://urlnx.com/JF2TSF
author: Yen G.

description:
Was attracted by the soju cocktail flight, however it seems they no longer have it :( 
Not very crowded on a Sunday brunch time, I guess it's a good option if you don't want a crazy and competitive wait. It is a bit off the popular areas of Fillmore and Japan Town, so there are plenty of street parking.
Ordered:
KFC: pretty good, but not very memorable
Soft shell crab benedict: I like it, especially it is not using the English muffin (which I never finished). The potatoes were my favorite though lol
Bulgogi BAP: AMAZING. We had our shared of good Korean food (from south bay, LA and NYC), so this was my least excited dish when we ordered it. Wow we were completely blown away! I would probably just drop in and get their Korean plates! The green onions on the bulgogi were the best!
author: Ya K.

description:
Had a birthday dinner here on Saturday. Great venue for large groups we had around 20 people. Very impressed with staff and service: team was super attentive throughout the evening and made sure everyone's food came out at the same time.

Fries, Tako Wasabi and Sniggle were big hits. Great place for dinner and drinks before continuing a night out - soju cocktails keep you buzzed but you won't be too drunk by the end of dinner.
author: Matt T.

description:
A decent Korean / fusion brunch spot in the Fillmore district that is worth stopping by if you don't want to head to Japantown. Get the budae jjigae if it's your first time here.

For a city as diverse as San Francisco, there aren't any especially good Korean restaurants worth noting. Although Fillmore Social Club is not the best Korean food you've had, the entrees are solid and the ambiance is pleasant. This restaurant has plenty of seating for parties large and small, and almost no wait time even on weekends.

The interior design of Fillmore Social Club is clean and well lit. It delivers what you expect of a brunch spot in SF - indoor plants and wooden floors and tables. Another plus are the large TV screens playing flashy K-pop music videos without sound. Sit facing the screen if you anticipate being bored by the conversation from the person in front of you.

I've had several dishes here, including the budae jjigae and the stone pot. The budae jjigae is spicy and the portions are quite large. They do fusion dishes well - the tofu salad was recommended to me as a good choice (actually didn't look so bad.) 4/5.
author: Chris W.

description:
I've been to their Berkeley sister restaurant, and this place definitely has a "cooler" vibe. The service is just as good, maybe even better than the Berkeley one. This place seems like it favors small plates and tapas over the bigger plates at the Berkeley one. No issues with service or anything like that, and they were happy to keep giving us more (and more and more) soju as the night went on. PS not too much in terms of vegetarian options, but what was on the menu was pretty tasty (according to my wife)
Definitely recommend if you need a place for a large group, or in the Fillmore.
author: Samir K.

description: I'm usually not a big fan of fusion asian places but this place was a pleasant surprise. The menu here is a funky blend of mainly korean and japanese influences. The place feels like a sport bar type place with tv, music, and a very chill casual vibe. For me it was the perfect place to stop by for a bite in the evening in the city where it wasn't too formal or too expensive. On my visit ordered several dishes, per the recommendation of server went more for their apps/taps-type options. Its mostly smaller bites bar food. I liked the shrimp pops and chicken karaage as they were both tasty and crunchy. Overall I thought this place as good cause I didn't hate anything we ordered. The service here was fast and friendly and the vibe was chill so its a place I'd come back to.
author: Peter P.

description:
Solid brunch spot in Fillmore. Came here with a party of 13 people and the restaurant was able to accommodate all of us. There's plenty of seating!

I ordered the Tofu Salad and was pleasantly surprised by the portion size. It was a big bowl of greens, amazingly soft and silky cold tofu, and tasty sesame dressing. Oh! And of course avocado. It was so good and surprisingly I finished the whole thing and still felt light. 

The rest of our party seemed to enjoy their food too. Many people ordered the ramen soup bowl and spam musubis. 

The service was very attentive and the restaurant played music and music videos to create a fun and casual atmosphere. Check it out if you're looking for a Korean Fusion brunch spot!
author: Jessica N.

description:
Large tables, great atmosphere for group hangouts.  I came here Saturday morning. Got seated right away because I had a reservation via Yelp. 

Food is Korean fusion with a twist of hip. I got the bulgogi rice and it was kind of bland... My boyfriend got the Korean KFC and waffle and it tasted way better. My plate came out to be $19 after tip and tax - overpriced for the quality. Wouldn't come back.
author: Angela T.

description:
What a cute place - love the K-pop videos on the projector. The interior gives off a clean and bright vibe. The food is so good! We got a bunch of dishes and shared - army soup/stew, chicken wings, kimchi pancake, tofu, etc... not remembering everything. Loved the army stew and the chicken wings. Those were my favorites. Comfort Korean food is such a go-to. The drinks were also delicious. They don't have high liquor drinks I believe, so everything is soju or sake based - but amazing. Definitely would come back here. I would want to come back here for brunch.

Ambiance: 5/5
Food and drink: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Overall Experience: 5/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Fillmore Social Club is one of my favorite places for an easy brunch, close location (to me at least) and solid food that isn't prohibitively expensive. They serve "Korean tapas", aka Korean staples that aren't strictly traditional. 

If you can't find parking, it's been fine for us to park at the nearby Safeway lot and walk the few blocks over.

If I had a complaint, the music is rather loud when I've been here, it's hard to have conversations.
author: Alicia W.

description: We were looking for a fun place for brunch that would seat 12 with no warning. The only place up to the formidable task was Fillmore Social Club. They had bottomless brunch and great food. I'm a sucker for Korean fusion. The food was a tad bit oily but was otherwise exceptional. I shared the Japchae, jazzy army stew and kimchi fried rice with two other people. The servings were very plentiful and we did not finish but the rice and japchae were amazing! Some people in our group got Bloody Marys and said they were a tad bit underwhelming. However those of us who got the bottomless brunch said the mimosas were delicious and the service was really prompt. Considering we were a large and unwieldy group the service was incredible.
author: Sharvari J.

description:
4.5/5

The food was delicious and nicely plated! We got the Kimchi Fried Rice, Musubi Benedict, and Hangover Shakshuka. The Kimchi Fried Rice was flavorful and had a lot of veggies that surprisingly went well together. My friend got the Shakshuka so I only had a taste of it but it was spicier than expected! My favorite was definitely the Musibi Benedict; the rice tasted like it was pan-fried, and spam and egg were tasty, the kimchi in the middle was a nice touch, and the potatoes were perfectly seasoned and crispy!

Love the wooden walls/chairs/tables and there are some really nice murals. The place is actually pretty big, and there was a birthday party going on in the other room.
author: Alice C.

description:
Came here to celebrate my cousin's birthday with a party of 5. They were extremely accommodating and we were able to make a reservation on a Friday night with no problems. 

I loved the ambiance of the restaurant - very hip, geared towards probably a younger crowd. The restaurant's main focus is Korean-Style tapas. We enjoyed everything that we ordered but the highlights were definitely the Millionaire's bacon, the Korean pancake and the octopus. They also had a variety of alcoholic beverages that sounded good. I think towards the later hours, it becomes more of a lounge/bar than a restaurant because the lights are dimmed and music is louder.
author: Patty L.

description:
This place is ever changing. Beautiful interior (gosh I remember Gussie's when it used to be here), and they've updated it so nicely. The menu has been changing as the restaurant is still figuring itself out. 

Asian meets Asian meets american meets African. It's definitely fusion!

We ordered too many dishes to count but here are some of my favorites that i would order again:

KFC (soy was my favorite)
Tuna tower (tuna tartare atop a crispy rice patty)
Galbi (short ribs)
Sniggle (Whole calamari bites with chips and rice balls)
Shrimp pop (shrimp tempura with Katsu glaze)

Things we ordered that I WOULD NOT order again:
Mini tacos
Pork belly
Chicken tender
K-nacho

Everything was bold in flavor, nice and steamy when served yet not overly seasoned. I rate this place above average for Korean inspired food. I find myself ping ponging between 3-4 stars. Food was good and tasty but i don't crave to go back. It's too easy here to rack up a big tab.

Potion size for the smaller plates is compared to tapas. 

Parking is a little difficult and the area is a bit unsure.
author: Karen H.

description:
This is starting to become one of my favorite brunch places. The decor here is modern, and the place gives off airy vibes, with natural lighting filtering through the large glass windows. When you first enter the restaurant, there's a decorated portion of the wall for you and your friends to take pictures. What a nice start to some basic weekend brunching!

My group of 6 came on a Saturday afternoon. There was no wait, as this place was quite big. We were seated almost immediately. The menu has clear hints of Asian fusion on it. I ordered the belly pot while my boyfriend ordered the bulgogi hash. My dish was absolutely scrumptious. The pork belly was soft and the thin cuts went so well with the fatty portions. The seaweed seasoning on top made each bite extra savory. The pot comes out quite hot, so some of the rice on the bottom cook for longer, making it very crispy and a wonderful pairing with the meat. The bulgogi hash was pretty good too, though I liked the belly pot better. 

The service was excellent and the place was really clean, so I'll definitely come back to give the other dishes a try.
author: Karen Y.

description:
This place is alright, definitely not a must re-visit for me. This is advertised as small bites like tapas korean fusion place.
We came here for dinner with some friends and ordered a few small bites and some main dishes to share. 
For small bites - We got the french fries with cheddar powder, chicken Karaage and the Millionaire's Bacon. The fries were a disappointment since it tasted like we were eating a small bowl of cheetos for $5? The chicken was ok but the star was the bacon. It was amazing and very flavorful.
For mains - we got the Spicy Pork Bap, K-Nacho, Sniggle and the Galbi. The spicy pork bap was nice, not too spicy and the ingredients was well-balanced. The K-nacho was pretty good, lots of toppings for all the chips underneath. The Sniggle (whole fried squid) was ok. The batter was too thick so you're eating a lot of oil and fried batter which made my stomach a little queasy afterwards. The Galbi had a funny taste to it, almost like they added too much bean paste or something. It just didn't taste like regular Galbi to me.
I do wish they provided those mini side dishes that you normally get at korean restaurants. Since Korean food tends to be meat heavy, it's nice to have some veggies to cut the fat.
author: Janet Y.

description:
The newest brunch spot from the owners of Blackwood, Sweet Maple, and Kitchen Story brings a Korean-centric menu into the mix. We came in Sunday 1 PM and there was pretty much no wait time. A party of ~10 walked in while we were there and the staff unfolded a wall to reveal even more seating. There is so much room here and unlike other brunch spots, tables are spread out so you don't feel crammed or right up next to your neighbor.

I ordered the French Toast, and the portions were so big that I couldn't even finish it. In fact, everything my party ordered had huge portions! Dishes were all gorgeously plated, and came out pretty quickly. I personally liked the French Toast the best, it was stuffed with slices of apple and cinnamon and the mascarpone was one of the best I've ever had. However the the Korean Fried Chicken was juicy and flavorful, and the Belgian waffle was nicely dense. Definitely come check this place out before waitlists start!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Visited with a party of 7 recently and had a wonderful time. No wait for brunch on Saturday AM and everything we ate was amazing

Highlights:
- Bottomless Mimosas (try the bitter! )
- Millionaire Bacon
-Bulgogi Hash
-Kim chi-fried rice
- Club Benedict! 
Sweet and savory- next time we are trying that French toast :-) 

Bright was amazing and made our day!

Couldn't have asked for better!
author: laura i.

description:
Same ownership  as the one in Berkeley. Love the decor, very comfortable seating and attentive service. You cant go wrong here. 

Best bacon ever!!! Try it and you wont regret it. Im not a huge pork lover but rhe bacon here makes me love it again!
author: Nyla J.

description:
3.5 stars!

I've only been here for dinner, but from what I can tell, this place is less Asian fusion as it is Korean fusion if that makes sense. The menu touted Korean dishes with a twist.

Korean fried chicken: This was heavier on the breading, which provided a good, thicker crunch. In contrast to the crisp, the chicken was dressed in moist sauces. There were 2 sauces, one resembling a sweet and sour, the other that was spicy. I don't recall if the pieces were white or dark meat, perhaps a mix.

Pork belly pot: Pieces of pork belly seasoned with a savory sauce, topped with sesame seeds and green onion atop white rice. It was definitely comfort food (not a fusion dish).

Shak shuka: This was an interesting concoction -  beef ribs in tomato sauce with melted cheese on top. Probably the most "fusion" of the dishes ordered that night. I think the novelty of the dish was initially a little hard to adjust to. The tomato sauce wasn't the traditional one used in pasta (I couldn't tell what additional flavors were there) and the different cuts of beef with cheese was a new experience. It was fine to eat that night but I don't think I'd order this dish again.

It's meat-centric here so probably not a great place for vegetarians/vegans. I do think all dishes could be lightened with the addition of vegetables.
author: Cici T.

description: A lot of friendly Thai staff here. They were able to accommodate 40+ of us for a big networking event. Their fried chicken was my favorite, comes in two flavors (sweet sauce and savory no sauce). Their tofu is super soft. We has a number korean dishes rice fried rice, korean pizza, bulgogi, and seafood. They were all flavorful. Their kimchi was so crispy and worth an honorable mention here.
author: Norases V.

description:
The Yelp reservation service is misleading, as there are only a few spots available for reservation. However, this is not a place that is packed even during peak hours, so feel free to stop by without reservations.

The menu is drastically different from when they opened (and from what is pictured on yelp), which I was not expecting. I was hoping to try a cocktail flight and have their kimchi fried rice for dinner. Unfortunately, neither were available on their current menu.

I ended up going with the Jaam Pong Ramen, which is a seafood noodle soup. My friend got the Bibim Ramen, which is a bibimbap but with ramen as the base - it is a dry noodle dish. We also shared the KFC. Everything was pretty tasty. I was actually pleasantly surprised with the Jaam Pong Ramen, which was chock full of different types of seafood (shrimp, scallop, mussel, squid), but it was a tad too spicy for me. My friend's Bibim Ramen was actually super flavorful and would be my choice for next time. The Jaam Pong Ramen also took FOREVER to prepare, another reason I would skip it.

Overall, an interesting restaurant with an unexpected atmosphere (ie. more sports bar/dive bar like), I definitely would not have expected a place like this to serve up Korean food the way they do!
author: Sherry L.

description:
Love this place, it reminds me of the bars you would find in Korea! Large space, so it's great for groups. I made reservations for a Friday evening at 9 PM but it wasn't needed. Loud music so that it drowns out other drunk convos nearby but funny awkward pauses when the music ends.

Food was pretty good! The food is more bar bites and meant to be snacked on while you drink soju or makkoli, just like in K-dramas. They give you some buttery popcorn to snack while you decided what to order. The tuna salad is slightly spicy, and it's more of a tuna poke. The kimchi Jun was more on the mushy side, it was dressed with Japanese mayo and Benito flakes. It was good but I was expecting Korean pancakes. I wish they had cheese corn, but will be back to try more items on the menu. FYI, there is a different menu from 6 PM-11PM.

Favorites: Pork Belly, chicken Karaage, triple fries (that fried bok reminds me of younger days), and cheese sticks.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Good brunch on Fillmore/Eddy with familiar choices for the millionaires bacon club. More Korean than Blackwood and different than Sweet Maple.
Suggest the spicy KFC to snack on and bitter mimosas for getting the day started correctly.
Club Benedict was enjoyable
author: Dave M.

description:
Came here for dinner! Loved the vibes of the place, and definitely my go-to late-night drunk food place if I'm ever in that area. Presentation was great as well!

However, while sober, the dishes were definitely too salty and sweet for me, even for Korean standards. Maybe their brunch meals are better, and maybe I should come back when I've consumed some alcohol?

We'll see!
author: Kathy Y.

description:
Steven Choi, you've done it again! From his many popular brunch spots in the bay ranging from Kitchen Story to Sweet Maple, Fillmore Social Club is one of the newest endeavors and also has the most Korean influence on the menu.

I came here with two friends on a Sunday afternoon. Although I easily made reservations for 12:15pm that same day, seating was so simple. I seriously loved that there was no wait at all plus the reservation option on Yelp! Hopefully this place doesn't get too popular like the others, as FSC has definitely become one of my top choices for brunch in the city now. (Best kept secret, for sure!)

For my meal, I ordered the Softshell Crab Benedict ($18), which I was so intrigued by not just from the presentation but the fusion of that American and Korean flair in brunch cuisine. The crispy softshell crab was a good size and gave such a yummy and crunchy texture along the creamy poached egg. To add, the side of colorful potatoes it came with are always spot on!

My friends ordered the Hangover Shakshuka ($15) and Chi Bap ($14), which I tried a bite of. I'm not really a big fan of shakshuka in general, but the tomato-based cause was nice and spicy --a real good kick of fire! As for the chi bap, it came on a beautifully crafted skillet of rice, shredded egg, and a nicely arranged tower of Korean fried chicken. I definitely loved how Korean fried chicken is extra crispy and saucy, so A+ in my book!

Of course you can't go to any of these sister restaurants without getting the Millionaire's Bacon ($8) added on as a side. I made sure my friends tried this item as they were visiting from out of town and they happily obliged. Seriously loved all the creativity and fusion of the brunch items at FSC along with the friendly and accommodating staff here. The dinner menu looks promising as well, so can't wait to come back for that.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
We love Fillmore Social Club, sister Company if Sweet Maple!

FSC hosted a birthday for my One Year old. We were in contact w/ the Restaurant Manager Yok a month prior. We went over the menu that we wanted & she gave us a price per kid & per child. Very easy & pleasant working w/ Yok.

On the day of the party, we arrived early and was blown away they were all set up! They even had balloons  for us.They just had to bring out the food in catering style trays.

Our Guest raved how great the food was, staff was excellent & atmosphere was so warm & welcoming! And FOUR restrooms.

For your next party...contact FSC! 

(Sunday, August 26, 2018)
author: Kenny C.

description:
This place was recommended by a friend since it was new so we thought we'd try it out. 

Not bad but much more of a drunchies place than anything else. It was pretty expensive and the portions are small. 

First impression, they asked if we had a reservation when we walked in but it was also completely empty so we were a bit confused. 

The staff were nice and pretty attentive throughout the meal. 

We ordered 7 dishes (2 appetizers, 1 soup, 4 mains and 2 sojus) and the bill came out to $200+ 

Mango poke salad - meh, would not order again. Small portion and not much fish at all 

Salmon tataki- good but only came with 4-5 pieces of salmon. 

Kimchi pancake- too much sauce on top so could barely taste anything else 

Moe Galbi-hard to mess up short ribs so they were good but everything else was meh. 

Jazz Army Stew- think spicy instant ramen with sausage and spam. Sadly the best part of the meal but it was a tad spicier than I could handle so I only had a small bowl. 

Hot tofu soup- not much flavor but it helped to balance the spicy ramen so worked out well. 

Soya- sausage and cheese, literally. Clearly we were starving when we were ordering. This was ok. 

Side order of kimchi was very good! 

The peach and banana soju would pass on next time. It was slightly carbonated and almost tasted like medicine :(
author: Shelly W.

description:
Our group needed brunch after a long weekend in Outside Lands. Visiting from SoCal, this place was a pleasant surprise and . Fillmore Social Club was a pleasant surprise with plenty of seating, Yelp reservations and generous portions. Our group of 4 were seated immediately after arriving at noon.

We tried the Kimchi Fried Rice, Soft Shell Crab Benedict and Jazz Army Stew while I got some type of crab toast (it was new to the menu at the time and I can't find it on any of the menus posted here or the website). We weren't huge fans of the stew but everything else was great. The Kimchi Fried Rice was very flavorful. The benedict and crab toast both came in large portions with plenty of roasted potatoes and a hot/sweet sauce that gives everything just a little more flavor. 

Entree prices varied but expect to pay around $16 for an entree. Only complaint is the drinks are pretty pricey. $9 for one mimosa or $20 for bottomless is pretty steep. Will be back to try the bulgogi or KFC dishes!
author: Damon L.

description:
Came by on a Thursday in March for lunch with a friend. Place was fairly empty which is nice since from my experience at Kitchen Story, waiting is usually part of the experience. Parking wasn't too bad on a weekday and we snagged a metered spot nearby. Service was friendly and I loved the look of the restaurant.

For our meal we ordered the following:
1) Moe Galbi: Friend's entree. Tried a bit. Flavorful galbi w/ a good char and marinade. Green onion salad was the perfect side dish. A decent portion but mostly it's the extra items vs meat. A bit pricey for $25 when you can get similar items/quality at any decent Korean place (3.5/5)

2) Pork Belly Pot: Once again a decent portion. Pork's flavor was there but nothing special. Most of our cuts were on the leaner side. Not dry but not juicy either. Eggs on top looked great but the dish really needed something to lighten it. (3.25/5)

3) Crab's Benedict: I don't know what happened w/ this dish. First the positives. The portion is very generous and the soft shell crab itself is delicious. Well fried, great batter, solid seasoning. Eggs were poached well. However, every other component of the dish was just strange. The consistency of the hollandaise was great but there was a flavor I just couldn't put my finger on. Not sure how to describe it besides "off". It wasn't flatout bad but I prefer a traditional hollandaise. Next issue was the english muffin. It was so so dense and hard. I shouldn't have to saw through my bread (and fail). However the biggest offender of the meal was the iceberg lettuce between my crab and muffin. Iceberg lettuce is the failure of the vegetable world and has no right being anywhere except a cafeteria side salad. (2/5)

Overall, my experience here was very average. I appreciate the creativity in the dishes but for the most part the items are close enough to a traditional dish that you can get an equally large portion of and at a better price with equal/better quality. I know the owner does take his businesses very seriously and my experience at Kitchen Story was mostly positive so I'm hoping this place will find it's stride with time. Maybe I'll give it another shot in the future.
author: Vivian C.

description:
It's remarkably hard (and shouldn't be) to find a good weekday breakfast in San Francisco.  You really have to hunt and peck to find much outside of downtown or your favorite locals haunt (like Outerlands in the Richmond or Zazie in Cole Valley.) 

Returning from a visit to the home of all day breakfast in Australia (breakfasts from Sydney to Melbourne were jaw dropping), my craving for big, beautiful mid-week breakfasts continues on, despite having to work much harder to find them stateside.

Fillmore Social Club in Western Addition (adjacent to Japantown) is serving up a solid, enjoyable mid-week brunch that includes several standout orders: KFC (Korean Fried Chicken) and blueberry waffle and a soft shell crab egg benedict. The plates are as colorful and inspiring as breakfast dishes we had in Oz, and I can appreciate the Korean fusion inspired cuisine and friendly service.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Went for dinner. Great interior and good service. 

I'd like to see more non-alcoholic beverage options that aren't just soda.

The food was all pretty good except the yogurt sauces which was nauseatingly bad.

I'd give it another try and could easily see me giving them another star.
author: Ryan B.

description:
A-okay for me and my friends. We came for brunch and were surprised it was so empty! But it was raining... and the place is pretty new, so I guess it makes sense. 

I ordered the hangover shakshuka, while my friends ordered the spam benedict, KFC and waffle, and the chicken katsu plate. We all liked our dishes, but we weren't really WOWed by anything. I guess I expected a lot because I heard Fillmore Social Club is ran by the same people that made Kitchen Story, Sweet Maple, Surinan, and Blackwood, so I expected more brunch dishes. However, I don't want to diss the hangover shakshuka because it was pretty good! It came with spam, bacon, kimchi, cheese, and rice cakes. I thought it was a fun Korean take on a traditional shakshuka. 

I would be down to come again for lunch or dinner, but maybe not brunch. The KFC here looks bomb!
author: Tara A.

description:
Cute trendy Korean fusion place! I came here for brunch with friends and it wasn't too busy for a Sunday around noon. We all liked the food and loved the atmosphere.

All the brunch foods were very hearty and homey. I had the Hangover Shakshuka and it was almost like an army stew/shakshuka fusion. It came in a large pan full of tomato sauce, spam, onions, mushrooms, two poached eggs, and crispy bacon with rice crackers on the side. It was my first time eating shakshuka - I loved the tomato flavor and how it tasted like a home cooked meal. The spam and eggs were delicious and the rice crackers brought some interesting texture (pro tip: soak the rice crackers in the sauce for a few minutes). I do wish they had added more bacon though - there were just a few pieces sprinkled on top.

My friends got the Kimchi Fried Rice, Jazzy Army Stew, and Musubi Benedict - all of which tasted great. The Musubi Benedict was a unique take on eggs benedict as it was served over rice with a side of salad and green mashed potatoes. They lit a small tea candle under the large bowl of army stew which hardly seemed functional but the flavor of the stew was delicious!

The service was a bit slow - the food took a long time to come out and we found ourselves with empty cups looking around for water. I'm not sure what kind of fusion the restaurant is going for - it seems eclectic as certain dishes fuse Korean cuisine with Japanese, American, and even Middle Eastern influences. But it works and I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Michelle L.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised with this joint. I made a reservation for 8, and glad I did, this place was pretty busy considering how new they are. The space is also quite large. They have a whole back section for larger groups.

We ordered a little bit of everything though. The Choice, like the squid but it would've been better not fried, the jazzy army stew that was recommended to us by our server, the bulgogi, udon with beef- where was the soup though?!?! It was just noodles and meat haha, poke, the half and half chicken wings, and kimchi jun. 

As for drinks we got their pineapple soju pitchers.  Bit sweet for my preference but had good flavor.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Stopped in for brunch today (7/1/18) with my pal who ate here before and knew we'd have food selections on the menu to satisfy both dedicated brunchers and well as Korean food lovers.
While my companion stayed true to her brunch leanings, I decided to venture out and have Korean food today.
I had the Bulgogi gab which was bulgogi beef meat, rice with a sunnyside egg on top. The dish also had a softball-sized mound of shaved green onion --really too much for one human to eat.
Since I like to be able to taste my food, I ignored the red, hot sauce in the little tin as well as the fiery-looking kimchi in another same tiny tin (never like to lose my sense of taste by masking my food with hot sauce; would prefer to save the tastebuds).
What did I think of my meal you ask? It was sort of meh. The food came out lukewarm (the meat could have been sitting under a heat lamp and just scooped up & put on the plate). Similarly the rice was tepid and a little hard so I wonder if it had been sitting out in the open air overlong.
The decor was nice and there are multiple rooms to accommodate various size parties. What I found most irritating was the difficulty in getting the attention of a server. It seemed like each server had blinders on and would dash into the room, drop off a dish and without looking up run out.
It took time for us to order and I noticed that a quartet of people who ordered after us got their food first!
This neighborhood lacks food eateries that are wholesome and Fillmore Street Social club does fill that void. But with the food served here as is, I'd rather venture further afield to find tastier food with more choices and without the big price tag.
author: Joanna T.

description:
Another restaurant opened by the same owners of Berkeley Social Club! 

Came here for a late lunch and we were basically the only people in the restaurant so service was pretty fast. This is a nice change from the hoards of people and 1 hour wait times at Berkeley Social Club so get on this before they become too popular!

CHI BAP $14 - soy glazed fried chicken over rice with shredded eggs and kimchi. The chicken was really good and the rice was cooked to a perfect crispiness on an iron skillet. 

SOFT SHELL CRAB BENEDICT $18: this dish was huge! It came with two whole crabs deep fried on top of a toasted sourdough muffin. Probably the most unique dish on the menu.

GALBI BAP $18: Short ribs with rice, a fried egg and kimchi. The ribs were nicely marinated but I thought this was the most average out of everything we tried.

They also have an extensive drink menu as well as bottomless mimosas. I would definitely come back and try their other options!
author: Angela P.

description:
We came for brunch on a Sunday morning at around 11am, and to our surprise, there wasn't a wait or a line, and the restaurant was fairly empty. The interior is very well decorated, with a modern appeal. 

I had been eyeing the soft shell crab benedict, and decided to order it; my friend went for the bulgogi hash. The food came out fairly quickly, and the plates were the perfect amount for a very filling meal. The soft shell crab Benedict came with two brioche-like buns, topped with two soft shell crabs drizzled with a teriyaki-type sauce, two poached eggs, and hollandaise (which I opted to have on the side). The soft shell crabs were very crispy, but a little too fried for my taste. The brioche buns were perfectly crunchy and buttery, and the teriyaki sauce on the soft shell crabs complemented the flavors well. My biggest concern were the poached eggs. Both mine and my friends' poached eggs were not poached very well, and they did not have the runny-yolk that is essential to a perfectly poached egg. My friend didn't look too amazed by his bulgogi hash either, but he said it was decent. The bulgogi hash portion was definitely more on the smaller side compared to the benedict. 

For a new brunch spot with interesting takes on breakfast food favorites, I would give this place a shot. Parking can be somewhat difficult, since all parking is street parking.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Brought my kids, age 11, 8, and 3 on our date night with the hubby and we were very pleased with our last minute choice in this spot. The staff was very sweet to the kids and had amazing service all around.

The name threw me off a little but this asian fusion was a great fit for the family.

Need to come back for their egg Benedict....
Pro: Food, drinks and service

The kids loved the: Shrimp Pop, KFC
The adults loved: Tuna Tower, lettuce wrap and poki
The kids and adults loved: Kimchi fried rice
Note the Mini Tacos were ok only

Drinks: I liked the YUZUBERRY better than COOL CUCUMBER
author: Asha J.

description:
First experience here:
1. Easy to make reservation  
2. Chic interior and big space
3. The dish I ordered was tasty (waffle and Korean fried chicken)

This place is definitely a great addition to the brunch scene in this neighborhood. There are a lot of great (but crowded) brunch option up in the Fillmore district north of Post, and a decent amount clustered around Nopa. Fillmore Social Club fills the gap between these two neighborhoods perfectly and can be treated as a stress relief for the ever so popular Sweet Maple. 

I've only had the waffle w/ Korean fried chicken here. The chicken was juicy and well flavored, while the waffle has great flavor but can improve on texture. The service staff was *very* attentive but could be a bit awkward occasionally. My friend wanted the French toast without bacon because she's vegetarian, but the waitress didn't seem to get it and tried really hard to push for not altering the dish. Not sure if this is a language barrier or personality, a bit more training on service be helpful. 

Can't wait to go back and try the lunch / dinner menu.
author: Rachel Z.

description: This place. Surprisingly quiet for a "social club" and the food is quite tasty for a "social club". It's a Korean place. They have Korean dishes that have a few modifications that I did not mind at all. The whole experience was a bit novel and familiar at the same time. I would go again. I don't think this was a typical place. What is going on? Not sure how to explain it. Solid food, solid place to chat with friends. Can't go wrong.
author: Young Y.

description:
Great experience. Tuesday night, had moderate business. We shared about 5 appetizer sized foods, and all were good, and I was satisfied (shared between 2)

Raw octopus - Good. Order it first, it's not a good finisher.
Fried japanese Chicken - Hot, fresh, tasty with good dipping sauce
Tempura Shrimp - On a stick, hot, fresh good sauce
Pork Belly - Crispy thin slices with a spicy bean dipping sauce
Lettuce bulgogi wraps - Surprisingly tasty

We also shared a bottle of sake and 2 beers, bill was about $40 / each, decent value
author: Jordan C.

description:
I always appreciate when new restaurants ask for customer feedback. 

While enjoying the Soju Cocktail Flight at Fillmore Social Club:

Server: "So, what do you think about the cocktails - which one is your favorite?"
Me: "I like the one with the roasted barley in it."

Server: "Oh yes, men like feeding their women this so they don't get fat!"
Me *pokes self*: "Yep, I'm several kegs too late for that one...", I thought to myself. 

Some people get offended over everything these days. You can't even fart in public without getting the stank eye. We're all human, it happens!

While some would have been offended to hear their server say something like this, I found it amusing. Well, awkwardly amusing but amusing nonetheless (it was a cultural thing and she was in no way malicious about it). Sometimes you just have to laugh it off.   

My friend, Mr. Diva is all about Asian Fusion cuisine so he wanted to try Fillmore Social Club, a Korean Fusion Restaurant that took over the old Gussie's location. Currently, in soft opening mode with a grand opening slated next month. Dinner only with weekend brunch in the next week or so (call to inquire). 

On the menu are an array of appetizers like ssam, poki salad, tataki, and entrees like Korean bbq, soups, and stews (budae jjgae). Korean food is never cheap and the most expensive item is their Galbi for $25 so prices are fair and it's in line with most Korean restaurants in SF. No complimentary banchan. Beer, wine, and soju only. 

While perusing the menu, I ordered the create-your-own Soju Cocktail Flight: Miss Jo (multigrain powder, whipped cream), Yakurtzu (yogurt, lemon, sea grass), Cool Cucumber (cucumber, lemon): http://bit.ly/2BmXuum. They were all delicious, though a bit too sweet. The Miss Jo, the one with the roasted barley and brown rice powder was my favorite, followed by the tangy Yakurtzu which is like a boozy Yakult, and then the refreshing Cool Cucumber. 

We had a hard time deciding on what to order because everything sounded great. Most of the Yelp pics were not captioned (*shakes fists*) so it was hard to tell what some dishes were. 

After some debate, we ordered the following: 

*Aji Fries: Deep fried spanish mackerel ($8): http://bit.ly/2G9i9Wk
I thought this would be fish "fries" but it was just fried mackerel filets. I enjoyed the golden brown crispy exterior but Mr. Diva said, it was too fishy. I would skip this. 

*Kimchi ($3): http://bit.ly/2DyoNYH
The kimchi had a good balance of heat and acidity so I didn't mind paying for something that's usually complimentary. It's was better quality than most free kimchi I've had. 

*Yaki Udon: Stir-fried udon w/ beef ($14): http://bit.ly/2DwctUL
It was a generous portion of yaki udon but I was hoping for more caramelization like a chow mein and for the noodles to have more of a chewy, bouncy texture. This dish was just ok and more soupy than I would have preferred.

*Half & Half KFC w/ gochujang, soy sauce, pickled radish ($18): http://bit.ly/2Dtj3LE
Good frying technique producing a nice crunchy KFC exterior that held up well to the gochujang. I prefer my KFC on the plain side (I like being able to enjoy the crunchy batter and moist chicken on its own) so I liked the lightly savory sweet soy sauce flavored one better. 

I think they use chicken tenders for their KFC. It wasn't dry but I prefer dark meat with bones for maximum flavor and moistness. 

*Moe Galbi: LA cut short ribs, green onions, mashed potatoes, pineapple ($25): http://bit.ly/2BnDhop
My favorite dish of the night, the galbi was rich, meaty, and flavorful (not msg-y). It was nicely charred for that smoky piquancy. The shaved green onions made for a nice slaw and the pineapples for a refreshing sweetness. The mashed potatoes were a bit cold. 

The staff is incredibly kind and very customer oriented. While I appreciate their attentiveness, it was awkward when some of the servers stood and stared at our table while eating (it was empty when we were there). Food service was timely and the Manager, who's super nice thanked us several times for visiting. 

Fillmore Social Club has done a great job remodeling the old Gussie's place. It's hip and inviting with playful wall art. It's a HUGE space...we counted nearly 90-100 seats so it's great for large groups. I hope they consider adding some music to set the mood. We were one of two tables there so it was eerily quiet. 

Overall, pretty good soft opening and their food has potential. IMO, it's better than Foxsister (The Mission) and more wallet-friendly than Namu Gaji (The Mission) which have the same Korean Fusion concept. 

With Fillmore 1300 and Yoshi's now closed, this street doesn't seem to get much foot traffic these days so I hope Fillmore Social Club gets more media attention and customers.

Hey, when you can't get a table at Bob's because you walked in a Saturday night with no reservations (!!!): http://bit.ly/2Dslazf, you can always come to Fillmore Social Club!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
What went wrong? For a "Korean" place, the waitstaff seemed thoroughly confused about the soju options. We wanted flavored soju, like yogurt or grapefruit. Not the mixed kind, but the branded kind. They were confused. It didn't seem like they had it. Then we asked if they had Fresh soju, which is the most common and classic soju brand that all Korean restaurants have. And they had no idea what we were talking about. We quickly realized this place was probably not Korean-owned, and none of their waitstaff were Korean. 

Their food was nothing special and quite frankly, overpriced. 
* The worst item was the Korean Fried Chicken ($18). It was SUPER battered and doughy, I felt very disgusting afterwards :/ Not like other KFC I've had before
* The Choice ($20) was a plate of rice cakes and squid heavily doused in spicy sauce... Couldn't really tell the quality of the food
* Dolsat ($20) with bulgogi was probably the best thing, but you can get this anywhere, and it's easy to make
* Whole Tofu Salad ($8) literally was a block of tofu in dressed in sesame oil. I was actually laughing when this came out because it was the whole block of tofu served in a pretty plate haha it was tasty though

I wanted to like this place so much but it disappointed. It has cool and hip decor but the atmosphere and experience felt off. Hoping they can get more experienced waitstaff, and actually get some real soju on their counters!
author: Vickie Z.

description:
I can't wait to get back here and try more food but I am afraid it will be gone by then. We went out here for dinner and it was dead empty at like 8pm early in the week, not a great sign.  

But the food though...

Great Asian fusion stuff in a modern atmosphere.  Awesome takes on traditional Japanese and Korean items like katsu and bulgogi.  We each had the Dolsot, which is basically a Bim Bim Bap and it was fantastic.  

Service was friendly and attentive, zero complaints.  But again, there was pretty much no one else there so they weren't that busy.

Please stay open so we can come by and try more food.  Please.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Came here for brunch and had:
- Army stew (4/5) - Basically spicy instant ramen soup with spam, bacon, and sausage.  Might not sound like exciting restaurant food, but it was really tasty and homey.
- Bulgogi hash (4/5) - Only had a few bites off my girlfriend's plate, but it was really well seasoned, and the potatoes, even by themselves, were delicious.

We'll definitely be coming back to try out the dinner menu.
author: Simon L.

description: My what excellent customer service! Although I didn't get to try to foods I wanted to partially because of the time constraint we had we still had an absolute great experience. Staff was friendly and knowledgeable. All the dishes we ordered did not disappoint! As we told our waitress, we will be back for more!
author: Teresa C.

description:
Best soft shell crab eggs benny ever! Loved it!!! Yuuummmy yum yum 

Service was okay... but the food was delish so honestly I don't care I'ld come back for seconds
author: Ani D.

description:
TL;DR - 50/50 for my two experiences here... go at your own discretion. My rating is soley based on my latest experience. 

First trip: A few months ago in April. The food was great (I think we ordered mostly korean dishes) Army stew, fried chicken, and bulgogi?
Yes, the service was a bit slow, but the staff more than made up for it. The food was actually really good that time. I remember making a mental note to come back here more often.

Cue.... last weekend's experience...

We ordered bottomless mimosas. The cups were pretty small and mostly ice. So Every time they poured in more mimosa, it was just very watered down until all the ice melted. Once the ice did melt... the little flowers frozen in the ice are awkward because it's rude to just spit out flower remnants... but some of the flowers were too tough to even chew. Yikes.

They also refilled pretty slow and took about 15 minutes for us to even get our first mimosa btw. 

The food. I got the korean fried chicken and waffles. Yuck. The waffles were HARD. Don't think you're getting a fluffy warm waffle. The waffle was dry and had the texture of hard stale crackers. The chicken was also incredibly dry. I found it so weird that the food was kind of luke-warm when it got to our table. Kind of like it'd be sitting out for a while. 

Oh well. At least its fairly empty on the weekends during brunch hours
author: Crystal Z.

description:
Great atmosphere, friendly staff, love their 
Brunch. Delicious food selections on dinner.
author: Adrian R.

description:
This place has potential. I think the concept is similar to that of cocobang and foxsister but it has a less casual vibe. Definitely targeted towards us millennial with this pan-asian fusion concept, BTS songs, and playful decor. Saw lots of couples dressed nicely for this place so maybe it's more a fancy date/pre-game place (at least at night). Haven't tried their brunch out yet but it looks not bad. 

I came at dinner but didn't order any drinks. There were a lot of empty tables (and rooms even) but I still had to wait 10 minutes to be seated because apparently most of the two people tables were booked (unsure why I couldn't have been seated at the 4 person tables?) I didn't mind waiting, just thought that it was a weird system. 

Anyway, because I wasn't drinking, nothing distracted me from the super greasy and salty soft bacon veggies($13). It came sizzling on a teppan plate which was fun but that food upset my stomach. My friend got a small ahi mango salad ($13) which was served in an edible crisp bowl but she wasn't very full afterwards. However the food was beautifully presented so brownie points to that!

Every waiter greeted us with a smile and checked up on us but slightly too excessively. Anyway, I'm sure this place is great for groups, people who want to turn up, and people seeking a certain vibe but the food could be better.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
Millionaire's bacon: sweet, smoky, salty, spicy. All the flavors of bacon done right.

Kimchi pancake: for a moment I thought I got an okonomiyaki since this came with bonito flakes & mayonnaise & okonomi sauce. A little soft, could have been cooked longer for a firmer and crispier pancake. 

Spicy pork bowl: came with ginger. Unexpected, but still good.

I'd prefer to give 3.5 stars since the pancake was a bit soft/soggy, but everything else was great.
author: Norman S.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night- completely empty so I am not sure if a reservation is necessary. Good luck finding parking in this area, it's very hit or miss. 

Coming from the same folks at Kitchen Story and Sweet Maple, you'll see the millionaire's bacon make an appearance on the menu. I passed on trying this but my friends who all did said it was orgasmic, so call it a must order if you eat pork.

What we ordered (besides the bacon)-

Tofu salad - very simple, but it was nice and refreshing compared to all the meat we ate
Ssam - good, but it was basically just bulgogi in lettuce cups so I'd order one or the other
Bulgogi - good, but I prefered the galbi
Moe galbi - probably my favorite item, wish there was more meat on those bones tho!
Half & Half - another stand out. there was definitely one of the sauces I preferred way more than the other tho. definitely a must order
Jazzy arm stew - don't think the table was a huge fan of this. The staff recommended it but it didn't really meet expectations

3 stars because for the price point, quality, and the servers were a little bit too forgetful considering we were one of three tables in the establishment. Interior of the restaurant is beautiful, maybe a little too dark for my liking.
author: Arezou A.

description:
If the Richmond is too far a jaunt for your Korean fix, Fillmore Social Club fills the void while adding a bit of flare in the process.

In the old Gussie's Chicken and Waffle space, this modern Korean concept brings a fresh approach to the cuisine's legacy in a way that pays homage to the past, yet tips a cap at the future. You'll see lots of familiar Korean staples on the menu--bibimbap, galbi, bulgogi, hot stone pots--but with a wrinkle that makes it unique. Items like chicken and waffles featuring Korean fried chicken instead of the usual Southern style, shakshuka which usually shows up on Middle Eastern menus, and wasabi musubi that's generally found in Hawaii dots the menu. So you can order traditional Korean fare, or spread your wings and try something not so typical--the choice is yours. But given my experience, you'll enjoy whatever route you strut down.

It's a good alternative for brunch, so instead of waiting in a 90 minute line at Brenda's or Sweet Maple on a growling stomach, try walking straight to a table here and move on with your day.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
After hearing that the Fillmore Social Club was owned by the same people as Sweet Maple, Blackwood, etc, I knew I had to check it out!  Stopped by for brunch with a few friends.  First and foremost, they have unlimited mimosas (for $20).  I would say we all enjoyed our food, and they had a couple vegan friendly options on the menu so they could accommodate everyone's dietary needs.  I think the price was a bit high given the portion size, but I'm sure the rent at this location must be outrageous so it's not surprising.  

I definitely plan to stop by for dinner at some point!  Glad to have another great restaurant in the area!
author: Paul W.

description:
This place is so cute and perfect for brunch! The entire restaurant is huge with plenty of seating. They can accommodate large parties and the couple times I've gone, I've never had to wait to get seated! 

The Korean fusion brunch dishes were very creative and flavorful. I really liked the kimchi shakshuka, but it was slightly strong. It would have been perfect with a side of rice haha. I also had the soft shell crab egg benedict, which came with huge portions. It was really good and filling! I would definitely order both again.
author: Hanna K.

description:
3.5 stars (if that were an option). Most points go to the super cute and trendy atmosphere and great service. Staff were very friendly and attentive!

I wish I could rate it just shy of 4 stars, because of the prices and small portions. I came here for dinner. We ordered the mango salmon poke salad, which was not worth it at all -- we found only 4 small cubes of salmon poke; the KFC half & half was pricey, but the soy sauced one was delicious; and the Moe Galbi was so tasty, but it was also pricey at $25 for a smaller portion than what you'd typically find at Korean restaurants. 

Sweet Garden & Matcha Mojito cocktails overall had interesting flavors and were OK-priced, but a bit too sweet for my palette.

I do think we need more Korean / Pan Asian spots, so I am a fan for that reason!
author: Jazzica D.

description:
Why the visit: A brunch joint in the city- why not?!  Also, based on Yelp! reviews, this is operated by the owners of Kitchen Story, Blackwood, Sweet Maple.  Again, why not :)

More of a 3.75 rating, so I rounded up.

Parking: Metered.

When: Saturday at 1:30p.  They take reservations- woohoo.  However, the establishment really wasn't that popping for the need to make a reservation.

Service: Attentive.

Food: More of a Korean selection, less of a brunch option.

Ordered: The FSC French Toast was quite decadent- you might want to hit the gym after this!  However, it isn't as greasy as the French Toast from Kitchen Story, so that's good.  Also, ordered the KFC.  The waffle was quite dense, and the chicken came out in strips.  Still the crunchy texture, but, I was accustomed to chicken pieces such as legs, thighs for instance whenever chicken and waffle is ordered.

Why I would come back: It might be just me, however, I have yet to find an establishment that has Budae Jjigae ("Army Stew") on their menus aside from K. Grill and Tofu House (https://www.yelp.com/biz/k-grill-and-tofu-house-san-bruno?osq=Tofu+House).  I love me some "everything, but the kitchen sink" stew- yummie!

Wishing this establishment much success.  I can see more foot traffic for those hankering for a place to grab a late night bite.
author: Jennifer K.

description: My wife and I held a 30 person birthday dinner here and Yokky plus the entire staff were amazing from start to finish!  We were granted a private room which we decorated as well as access to their TV to play whatever we wanted (ended up bringing a Nintendo Switch!).  The food is absolutely delicious and there was more than enough for everyone with plenty of leftovers.  Highly recommend for both small and large parties!!
author: Bryant L.

description:
We chose this place for dinner because I drove and we wanted to stay away from areas where we cant find parking, so here we are! I also ALWAYS love trendy asian fusion places, and this is exactly what it is. There are parkings around this place, but it still takes some effort to circle around though. However, reallllly not that bad given SF standards. 

This restaurant is not one of those super small place with only 4 tables. This place is HUGE. You will never have to worry about waiting, I don't think. 

We were greeted and seated right away when we came in. Awesome. We order some flavored soju first, and then each ordered our plates. I got the fried chicken, my friend got the bibimbap and the beef thing? I personally think the chicken was so yummy. I mean I've been to bonchon and stuff, but I always find bonchon too dry so I never went back. This place... the sauce was SIMPLY amazing. I highly recommend the chicken. However, I think the bibimbap and beef dish had a good presentation, was good, but not wowing though.The portion is really good for one person as well. I definitely had leftover. 

I had a really solid dining experience here. I think this is a great place to meet up with friends or go on a date, just because its spacious and quiet enough to talk. I would like to try the brunch here some day :)
author: Jen K.

description: A girlfriend and I came here for dinner because we heard this is from the same owner of Berkeley Social Club and I LOVE Berkeley Social Club! I was super excited to try this place but unfortunately the food was pretty disappointing. To start, we got the Spider which was the soft shell crab and it tasted like ocean water. I'm not sure if this was even cleaned properly before being cooked, but it left a nasty after taste in my mouth. I'm not one to waste food, but I really couldn't finish it. We also got the spring rolls with glass noodles and Army stew and both items were also mediocre. Nothing really impressed me so I will probably not make a trip out to the area just to eat here.
author: Chi L.

description: Stopped for lunch on a Sunday. There was no wait, which was great. The food selection was pretty good - has some asian fusion lunch dishes and classic brunch dishes. My friend got the crab Benedict and I got the pork over rice. They were both really good but I thought it was a bit pricey! Paid about $20 for a dish and a cup of coffee.
author: Theresa H.

description: My husband and I came for Saturday brunch. We made a reservation for 10:30am but we didn't really need it. The restaurant wasn't very full, but I enjoyed that it wasn't too crowded. I ordered the soft shell crab Benedict with fruit instead of potatoes. The crab was a good size and very meaty. So much flavor in this dish! The fruit was well worth the extra $3 because it was a cup full of high quality fruit (blackberries, blueberries, strawberries, grapes, and oranges). My husband got the waffle and kfc and was pleased with his meal as well. Service was good. The price was right. Overall a great place for brunch!
author: Aubrey S.

description:
After trying multiple of the owners' other locations, I'd have to sadly admit Fillmore Social Club is the least appetizing to me. I very much favor Surisan that's located in North Beach for the same Asian fusion cuisine offered here. 

We stopped by for dinner and ordered the Triple Layered Pork ($9) which was delicious, but came with only about 3 thin pieces of pork on a bed of green onions. We also had the Half & Half Korean Fried Chicken ($18) and the Moe Galbi ($25). The Korean Fried chicken was really tasty and had a lot of flavor, and came in large portions on top of some mixed lettuce. The Moe Galbi came out on a sizzling plate with grilled pineapples and green mashed potatoes. This was also average, but I've had comparable Galbi at places like Cocobang for a cheaper price. 

For the price we paid, I don't think it lived up to expectations in comparison to Berkeley Social Club or Surisan, but the decor, vibe and feel is really great inside the location. I'd recommend stopping by if you have a big group of friends and are able to try more of their appealing appetizers.
author: My N.

description: Fall in love with their environment​ !!!!! So lovely!! The Korean​ mural is the main element in the space. They also have private event space as well, it is a good place to go if you wanna gather​ a group of person​ to celebrate​e something​.
author: Faye L.

description:
Relatively new, so get your brunch in before it becomes another Sweet Maple with lines out the door!

Walked in a little after 9am, and only one other party was seated.  I love undiscovered brunch spots.  They have a breakfast and lunch menu available in the morning, but my friend and I were in the mood for eggs so we got the spam benedict.  The dish comes with rice as a base instead of English muffins, and with the hollandaise it was amazing!  Something I definitely would want to recreate at home.  We also got the ssam tacos and a side of KFC.  The ssam tacos were way more ssam than taco, but pretty good.  KFC was more like chicken karaage, not really what I was expecting.  All in all though, the food was solid, and the coconut latte my friend had was delicious.

Our server was so sweet, she kept reminding us to take our time because the place was very obviously not crowded.  They let us sit and enjoy our drinks and chat as long as we wanted.  It was very welcoming with great atmosphere.

Tips and Tricks
-Desserts aren't super exciting, I would just order a side dish or a latte if you have extra room
-Each entree comes with salad and mashed potatoes, kind of weird but both were tasty
author: Jessica L.

description: Just an outstanding brunch.  Korean-brunch fusion is rare and sounds tasty, but tough to pull off.  Fillmore excels not just in the Korean area but also the fusion.  We had the kimchi fried rice off the Korean menu as well as the soft shell crab benedict.  Of course we also had to try a tender and the Millionaire bacon.  To begin, the bacon was great.  I was expecting a small piece based on reviews but was actually pleased when it came with two large pieces of thick, pepper-packed bacon.  Really great tasting and perfect in any brunch dish.  The tender was a little dry but better than most chicken pieces.  The kimchi fried rice very good and egg stayed cooking on the hot stone pot which is perfect.  Finally, the soft shell crab benedict was terrific.  Humongous soft shell crab that was actually tough to finish due to its size.  4 types of potatoes on side finished the dish off.  The soft shell crab was quickly recommended by the server and I 100% agree.  This dish is fantastic and one of the best brunch dishes I've had.  Truly fusion and truly a must stop.  Easy to get a seat even on a weekend and service was fast (even too fast) with food on the table within 15 minutes.  Bottomless mimosas on weekends on top of everything, for only $20, make Fillmore one of the best spots this part fo town.  Really a high quality brunch and well worth coming back.
author: Zachary A.

description: Love this place, especially with a lot of street parking within a couple of blocks. Everyone is very welcoming and the restaurant has a nice relaxing feel. We like Korean food and Asian fusion so this was a good fit for us. Food was good, drinks were good and service was good. We ordered a variety of dishes but all of them were tasty. If you like Korean food and Asian fusion, I think you will enjoy this spot
author: Michael A.

description: This place reminds me a lot of Surisan in terms of dishes and vibe. I came here for dinner with friends and ordered a few drinks and the following dishes: Tofu Salad, Triple layered pork, The Choice, Sookjo Bacon, and Chop Steak. I really enjoyed the tofu salad and the dressing it came with as well as the tenderness of the Chop Steak. Overall, the rest of the dishes were just ok. Good but not memorable. I also found a lot of them to be on the salty side. The most underwhelming dish would have to be the Triple Layered pork, which were around 5-6 small slices of pork belly with ssamjang on top. The presentation of the dishes were beautiful but flavors were lacking in complexity. Awesome service though!
author: Sui N.

description:
i'm at FILLMORE eatin in my fillmore stance
hurry up n gimme the SOCIAL b4 i CLUB in my pants
the mad order of apps n my entrees r fooded
i dine heavyweight n still undisputed :p

u took SOFTSHELL CRAB out my mouth bland eat a meal in my seat
i paid so many eats i feel makin it rain n i'm satiate
excuse me for example PAJEON was ok tasty but mushy

n unless u got DRANKS FLIGHT ain't inebriation
a foodment of ur imagination
b b b but wait it gets real!
HALF & HALF CHICKEN tastiest of my meal
comin through w menu windowseat view
tourists order too n just just chew!

dup duh dup dup duh dup
friendly service
eat dup duh dup dup duh dup
give em time foodwise
eat dup duh dup dup duh dup
stars 3.5
author: Dan B.

description:
Here for a casual Saturday dinner. Huge space, lots of tables so no wait. 

Modern, upscale korean restaurant with excellent service.

We had the tako wasabi, jazzy army stew and shashuka backribs in tomato sauce. They were all good tasting food but nothing stood out in particular and certainly were not worth the price premium. For the same price point, we much favor Surisan, which is more innovative korean fusion. Tako wasabi was fine (3.5 stars); army stew was prob our favorite with great soup base but overpriced given the portion (4.5 stars); backribs in tomatoe sauce (3.5 stars) was good with the sauce, but the meat itself could be more tender and flavorful. 

TLDR: good korean food with great ambiance, but overpriced
author: Nancy Z.

description:
OMG! What a surprise! 
On this Sunday morning, originally I had the mood for Sweet Maple's breakfast on Sutter Street, but when I drove by, the line was almost a block. Oh well, I decided to try Fillmore Social Club because it's under the same ownership as Sweet Maple. At first, I couldn't find street parking around Eddy & Fillmore Street, but as I was driving around, I noticed that public parking is just in front of Fillmore Social Club. 
I only had to wait just a little moment for the table. 
I had Cali Scramble, Mimosa and Coffee. What a surprise! I just loved what I had. There are only handful places in town for great brunch, and this place is certainly one of them. I also loved their mixed potatoes w/ my Cali Scramble. For my drink, I could taste that they use good champaign for Mimosa mix as well. Bottomline: Taste great and no line, I can't ask for more. Oh, servers were very friendly too.
author: Annie K.

description:
Date & Time:  Tuesday January 2, 2018 @ 7pm
Dining Companions:  Mommy & Husband
Scene:  Couples & Small Groups in White Faux Fur Coats over Black Dresses & Over-the-Knee Boots
Decor:  Architectural Digest Worthy.  Reclaimed Woods, Colorful Art & Fancy Wall-Paper.  
Service:  Young, Fun, Hot w/ Impeccable Manners on Top of That
Imbibe:  Soju Cocktails $9-$10 Marshmallow Latte(Soju, Double Espresso, Caramel, Toasted Marshmallows, Whipped Cream), Cool Cucumber(Soju, Cucumber, Lemon), Yakurtzu(Soju, Lemon, Yogurt, Sea Glass), Melting Love(Soju, Icing, Lemon, Cotton Candy, Sugar Stick), Matcha Mojito(Soju, Matcha, Mint, Whipped Cream)
Devour:  Aji Fries $8(Fried Spanish Makerel), Ssan $10(Marinated Ribeye Wrapped in Lettuce & Picked Radish), Yaki Udon $14(Stir Fried Udon w/ Choice of Beef or Pork), Half & Half $18(Korean Fried Chicken Two-Ways), The Choice $20(Fried Whole Squid w/ Rice Cakes & Trio of Dipping Sauces), Shakshuka Baby Back Ribs $22(Braised Ribs)
Total:  $122.36
Note: Thank You 2017, Welcome 2018!
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
I went here on a suggestion from the GF's friend. Normally I am not a huge asian fusion fan but this thai/korean/american gastropub type place was pretty decent. 

I had the shakshuka mainly because I enjoy pronouncing the name of this dish. It was tasty a fairly large portion and very enjoyable.

The rest of table had the crab cake benedict that seemed flavorful and delicious.

We went on a mother's day and while it was more for a mini family reunion than mother's day I was pleasantly surprised that it was low key not too busy and the service was great.

One thing though is it's pretty loud with the music there. I don't really care too much about that, but one of our guests had a baby and it made it sort of rough on the baby. 

Not necessarily the restaurant's fault but something to keep in mind if you have kids.
author: Theo S.

description: First time here and enjoyed all the food . Loved the spicy Tuna tartare and the nachos , my favorite drink was the cool cucumber . Service was good and walked out of there satisfied.
author: Jose M.

description:
TL;DR Another addition to the Kitchen Story owners' chain of restaurants that doesn't disappoint with great food and a large seating capacity! 

Yes, same owners as Kitchen Story, Sweet Maple, Blackwood, Surisan, Berkeley Social Club and a couple others. I could leave my review at that and you would probably be able to guess what this restaurant is like. 

FSC is a Korean influenced restaurant tucked on Eddy St. I rushed my boyfriend out the door to the restaurant at 11:30am on Sunday expecting a line, but it was actually fairly empty. We were seated quickly close to the hand painted mural and I got to observe the whole restaurant. It was well lit with a natural colorful wood vibe, reminding me of Hawaii. 

I ordered Chi Bang, which is Korean fried chicken served over rice in a cast iron skillet ($14) and my boyfriend got the soft shell crab Benedict ($18). My chicken was super flavorful, saucy, and crunchy and I got like 9 pieces of chicken! The skillet was coated with a sweet soy sauce before the rice was added so there was a wonderful sweet and crispy taste as I mixed up my rice. The crab Benedict was literally 2 whole crabs deep fried and placed on sourdough toast with eggs on top with a side of herbed mashed potatoes and salad (bf asked for hollandaise sauce on the side). 

Like all their restaurants, presentation was over the top beautiful and the food was delicious. As the newest in the chain of brunch places, there isn't much of a wait (or none at all!) at FSC so I would definitely give it a try before it gets packed!
author: Barbara C.

description: This place seems to have everything it needs to be a successful spot ... but the food was just okay for Korean food. We ordered the chicken karage (it came looking like chicken fingers which was a surprise), army stew (quite tasteless), and some other dishes which were not memorable.
author: Emily Y.

description: We stopped in here for some appetizers and drinks before we went to a concert down the street. The spring rolls were really good. We also tried the soft shell crab and avocado mashed potatoes.  The drinks were good and the crab was outstanding. I would highly recommend checking this place out.
author: Josh Z.

description: Good for groups and they have party plates. and a lot of variety of small plates. I will go back to this place.
author: Jenna F.

description:
First time in here we heard this place is the new Korea restaurant in Fillmore  They serving Asian Korea fusion  we been here for dinner with the big group of friend 
Thank you Chan u do a great job :) 

We order 
the choice  deep fry squids 
S.S. Sunomono
The spider  
Chop steak 
Grill Scallop
And. TAKO WASABI

Drink : cocktail & Suju , Beer 
 
Food : good Asian fusion taste is good 
Parking : street parking ( easy parking)
Location : Fillmore nice decoration 
Service : Good of service 
Price : reasonable price $$
Reservation : they do , or walk in
 I recommend u should come to try it here :)
author: Chef Tickets S.

description: Very cute, trendy place, bustling with people. The servers were good except for one guy who kind of huffed about giving my friend a straw. I had a pumpkin salad. The pumpkin was good, but for the price there was a lot of water at the bottom of the dish, like a pool around the pumpkin mash. So I think the flavors were nice but all got diluted by this water, which made it a little disappointing.
author: Julia S.

description:
OMG!!!
I can finally say there is a great Korean restaurant in San Francisco!!
super cute interior with unique fusion Korean food.
I found this place throw yelp and I'm so glad I did.
Fillmore social club is soft opening now. however, I would say this place is better than any other Korean drinking spots in the city. this place serves creative soju cocktails, outstanding fusion korean dishes( I guess the chef has Japanes background). all of dishes I ordered were very delicious and superb. I ordered soft tofu salad with kimchi, grilled scallops, half and half(soy glazed and sweet and spicy chicken),  deep fried whole squid with rice cake and potato chips, saute bean sprouts with bacon. LITERALLY, everything was so good!! also Fillmore social club is going to open for brunch in a week or two according to the manager(Chan). Can't wait to try their brunch!!
author: Woong C.

description: Came here twice now and have had pleasant experiences both times. At this point, we've tried almost everything we can on the menu save a couple of items -- from what we've ordered, the shakshouka baby and half/half chicken were the highlights. Great presentation of food, lots of seating, friendly and attentive service (although sometimes a bit too involved, although I suspect it's due to the recent opening). In terms of cocktail, the yuzu berry is a delicious must-have. I'm not a huge fan of cocktails but I thoroughly enjoyed it. Looking forward to coming back here :)
author: David Y.

description: Honestly very mediocre food :/ I wanted to like this place more but everything came out in tiiiiny portions (yes, I understand this is bar food and it's small bites style, but even the bowls were barely a serving). The food was mostly lukewarm and awkwardly composed (bulgogi nachos were bland and had huge chunks of meat that were impossible to eat with the chips...). It was also extremely overpriced and came to about $50 for two people. We were barely full afterward. Cute concept but the execution leaves something to be desired.
author: Esther Y.

description: Great food love the vibes and pretty display! Went here with friends and had a great time
author: Amy L.

description:
I'm very sad about Fillmore Social Club..

When it opened they were offering up awesome food and drink at a fairly reasonable price. The soju-only cocktails were excellent and potent. The vibe was usually lively but not in your face or too loud. It was honestly one of (if not) my favorite restaurants in the city to go grab a bite to eat whether by myself or with friends.

Yesterday I went over for dinner and things were...different. 

Flashing lights, balloons, pitchers of uninteresting frozen cocktails with no commitment to soju, towers of beer, a wheel to spin for free shit when you walk through the door, and a completely different menu. And the party vibe just felt so forced. What happened? Where is my "The Sticks"? Where is the "Cool Cucumber"?

I assume business wasn't going well for the restaurant concept, which is super unfortunate because I loved it so much - as did everyone I went there with.

That being said, the folks working there are among the friendliest and most inviting staff I've ever encountered. I want their business to succeed.

I think maybe the new bar/lounge could work if it was say...a switch they flipped on the weekends while sticking to the original formula during the day. I'm sure they're also working out the kinks of the new concept and this will feel a lot better in a month or so. 

Right now, though I just feel so confused by this choice.
author: Andrew P.

description:
Korean fusion restaurant where they serve good selection of brunch, lunch and drink menus.

As I was hung over a bit from the night before, passed the alcoholic drinks and ordered a coconut latte and my friend ordered matcha latte both whip creams. Yumm!

For food, I got the soft shell crab benedict which I barely finished one out of two being served. Their portions are very generous and the quality of the food and atmosphere was great. I had a minor issue with my coconut latte but the staff quickly made a new one for me, took it out from the bill and very very politely apologized multiple times about their mistake. Was impressed by how they amended the situation so nicely!
author: Jaz H.

description:
I needed a place to meet a friend for a last-minute meeting. We decided to try the FSC and I will definitely go back.

Food and drink - Inventive and tasty.
Service - Amazingly attentive, friendly, welcoming
Price - Reasonable
Ambiance - Great music, fun videos projected on the wall

Great neighborhood spot.
author: Marjorie A.

description:
Perfect spot to grab food before a show at the Fillmore, which is 3 blocks away.

Portions are nicely sized (the "not too big, not too small" descriptor in the menu is accurate), prices are reasonable for what you get, and the service was super fast!

I got the Yaki Udon, which was delicious and had a great mix of veggies and bulgogi. My girlfriend got the avocado bap which was tasty but a little less zesty. The KFC was amazing.

The only knock I have is that the drink portions are small.
author: Woody K.

description:
Outstanding experience. We visited for brunch. I ordered the Hangover Shakshuka and also tried a friend's KFC and Waffle. Both were excellent and I'd recommend either one depending on whether you're looking for sweet/savory or bold/spicy. Personally, I liked the Shakshuka better. Our waitress recommended it because it has a nice wake-up kick to it, and I would agree. Delicious. Although I will say that it was A LOT of food. I had difficulty finishing it (but of course I did because it was too good not to). It almost could have been enough for my girlfriend and me to share. 

Anyway, service was excellent, wait staff was enthusiastic and offered good recommendations, and the best part was that it's still a new enough place that we didn't have to wait for a table. Highly recommend and would go back.
author: Chris P.

description: This place is below my complex and it always has available seating , which is something I like. Last night my husband and I ordered 4 orders: kfc chicken (too sweet for us) nachos w some beef (also very sweet),  shrimp pops (AMAZING) and this tuna ceviche looking thing on crispry rice (Amazing). I honestly don't know the names bc the menu last night is not on Yelp page. Either way, the fish dishes were so good, prices great & service good. *They don't have quality wines, but specialize in cocktails FYI.
author: Shira T.

description:
I give this place 5 stars in a lot of categories:

5 stars for Ambience.
5 stars for Service and the Staff.
5 stars for how quickly our food arrived.
5 stars for the presentation of the food.
5 stars for how well the chicken was cooked.

The only thing that makes me hold back on giving the complete experience 5 stars is for my expectations going in for the taste of the food.

I got the fried chicken for my entrees, and I expected it to be very hot spicy, but what I got was actually sweet and mild.

For appetizer, I ordered chicken with cheese sticks. While the sauces we're delicious, and the chicken was perfectly cooked, on it's own, it didn't have much flavor on its own. Which is fine, if you prefer a plain fried chicken with amazing sauces. But I prefer my chicken to come seasoned with some original flavor of its own.

I think this restaurant has great potential! I'll definitely go there again and try out more dishes.

The staff is the nicest and most friendly staff I have ever seen. Upon hearing my thoughts on the food, they said that I can always ask the food to be made with more heat - something that I will definitely do next time!
author: Gaurav M.

description: Great brunch place.  Had the soft shell crab Benedict and the Korean fried chicken and waffles.  Both were delicious.
author: Shawn A.

description: Ya ya ya ya yaaasss!!! This place does it right. It hasn't been open for long but they already have it down. We went with 6 people on a Friday night and we all loved the food. The server was really helpful in making solid trustworthy suggestions on what to order. We rocked it family style and everyone was stoked and walked away with full bellies. Will def be back for another round.
author: Terese O.

description:
Musubi Benedict and M & M French were perfect and there are so many choices of cocktail for brunch. I highly recommend Yukurutzu for cocktail! 
Even the service was perfect!
I think this is gonna be an one of my favorite restaurants in SF for sure!
author: Haansol R.
